page.title: 17HOLME VALLEY HOUSING (2)
page.content: The first major break from the use of thse traditional materials came with the building of council house estates. One in Honley is of red brick homes, semi-detached or in short terraces. After Local Government changes in 1974, the Holme Valley was designated as suitable for housing development. That which has since taken place has been mainly in the private sector. These estates of detached and semi- detached homes have climbed up the valley sides reducing woodland and farmland. They are often of artificial stone construction although real stone is still used for the more expensive. In the valley bottom some clearance and renewal has taken place. At Berry Brow this resulted in the construction of two tower blocks of flats which have been subject to some criticism.
